Award.AbstractNarration:
A complete understanding of the history of our universe is not possible without addressing the problems of singularities in classical gravity. Singularities, such as the big bang, are the boundaries of classical space and time where the classical physics stops. These singularities signal that the underlying theory, in this case Einstein's theory of General Relativity, has reached its limit of validity. Answers to fundamental questions such as the birth of the universe thus cannot be obtained using general relativity which is based on the classical notion of space and time. It is expected that a quantum theory of gravity would reveal new physics which provides important clues on the resolution of singularities. In this research, loop quantum gravity is used to explore the fate of singularities in different spacetimes, including cosmological and black hole spacetimes. Lessons from these investigations will be important to understand the quantum nature of spacetime, the physics of the very early universe and the final stages of the gravitational collapse.

Research carried out in this project deals with analytical, phenomenological and numerical investigations of isotropic, anisotropic, black hole and inhomogeneous spacetimes to understand singularity resolution using techniques of loop quantum gravity. By a systematic study of quantization of these spacetimes and its relation with the effective descriptions, precise physics at the Planck scale will be extracted and phenomenological implications will be explored. This research also aims to address fundamental issues pertaining to the quantum probabilities for events, such as the quantum bounce, in a quantum universe. These investigations are expected to give valuable insights on the generic resolution of singularities in quantum gravity.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Though extremely successful in describing dynamics of our universe and astrophysical objects when gravity is weak, Einstein's theory of general relativity fails at the cosmological and black hole singularities. Due to existence of these singularities, Einstein's theory can not provide answers to fundamental questions about the birth of our universe, and, similarly what happens in the deep interior of the black holes. At singularities, the gravitational attraction and the curvature of space-time becomes
infinite. All known laws of physics break down at the singularities. It has been long expected that a marriage of quantum and gravity would provide insights on these fundamental issues. The goal of this NSF project was to discover new physics at this union and provide answers to some of the long standing questions on resolution of gravitational singularities.

In this NSF project, we applied insights from loop quantum gravity to understand resolution of singularities. Lopo quantum gravity is a candidate theory of quantization of gravity based on quantizing the dynamical gravitational space-time. Key predictions from this theory include discretenss of geometrical quantities such as areas and volumes. This discretenss only becomes apparent when one probes extremely high gravitational fields, or when the the curvature of the spacetime approaches Planck scale. Methods from this approach were applied for a variety of cosmological, anisotropic ad black hole spacetimes in our investigations. Our research involved extensive analytical, phenomenological and numerical studies. HIgh performance computing was used for the first time in studying resolution of singularities.  We found various novel results.  We discovered that loop quantum gravitational effects result in a generic resolution of singularities in different spacetimes. This is a very  significant result which proves the robustness of singularity resolution in these studies, earlier found for isotropic cosmological models. The big bang singularity is found to be replaced by a bounce in all the models studied so far. Thanks to the use of high performance computing, extreme regions of Planckian space-time could be probed which led to another novel result that one can effectively replace quantum geometry with a continuous geometry with additional modifications. These modifications encode key elements of quantum gravity and were used to understand various phenomenological consequences, such as for occurence of inflation in the very early universe.

Resolution of black hole singularities was another key result in our research which involved proposing new models and numerical simulations to understand the deep interior of Schwarzschild black holes. Our research also focused on understanding fundamental issues of quantum probabilities in quantum space-time. These studies allowed us to answer questions about probability of occurence of singularities, or bounce, in a definite way.
